In Julia, Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

Here is the code snippet for your problem in Julia:

```julia
using Dates

function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime=now(), bump::Int=3)
    if typeof(dt) == DateTime
        return dt + Hour(bump)
    elseif typeof(dt) <: Date
        throw(ArgumentError("Only DateTime types are allowed, not Date type."))
    else
        throw(MethodError())
    end
end
```
This function takes a `DateTime` and an integer `bump`, defaults to now if no argument is provided. If the inputted date-time is of DateTime type, it will return the new datetime after bumping the hours. If the inputted date-time is of Date type, it will throw an ArgumentError saying "Only DateTime types are allowed, not Date type". For other data types, it will throw a MethodError saying that the method for this data type doesn't exist.
